asset.taxonomy: opinion/Donald Trump à la Mode (14bruni)
asset.assetTitle: Donald Trump à la Mode (14bruni)

comments.commentBody: There is nothing surprising any more in any story about this 2-year old man-child throwing temper tantrums. The surprising thing, or as Bruni calls it "a thing of absolute wonder") is the number of Republicans who have lost their self-respect and credibility straining themselves to rally to his support. I wonder if they know that when he leaves office in 3+ years (unless there is a successful impeachment) they will be left high and dry and called upon to defend their actions. I'm very curious to see the webs they'll weave and the contortions they'll get into to explain themselves. For that I cannot wait.

asset.assetTitle: Is President Trump Obstructing Justice? (14kristof)

comments.commentBody:
With every passing day and every new move by 45, America is looking less and less exceptional.
"Make America Great Again" ought to be replaced with "Make America Lilliputian Again." But of course The Donald would ask if Lilliputs are really Giants with great big endowments.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Donald Trump Does Not Surprise (14douthat)
asset.assetTitle: Donald Trump Does Not Surprise (14douthat)

comments.commentBody:
"Donald Trump Does Not Surprise" says the screaming headline of a Douthat column in the second year after the anointed hero descended on an escalator to loud blaring music.
Equally true is that Douthat does not surprise us any more. His conservative and religious pontifications are wearing thin.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/When Will Republicans Stand Up to Trump? (12boot)
asset.assetTitle: When Will Republicans Stand Up to Trump? (12boot)

taxonomies.name: When Will Republicans Stand Up to Trump? (12boot)

comments.commentBody:
Trump has violated the anti-nepotism statute. He is more than neck deep in the conflict-of-interest ocean. He has shamelessly used his office and allowed his family to use his office for personal gain.
And, in what must be bitter irony, he goes on a campaign rally (most recently in PA) and gets the crowd to join him in chanting "Lock her up."
It is time that the GOP separate themselves from this man. But with so many Americans in a trance, I'd say "We-the-People" are to be blamed much more.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Owning Your Own Future (10friedman)
asset.assetTitle: Owning Your Own Future (10friedman)

comments.commentBody:
"Stop asking a young person WHAT you want to be when you grow up. It freezes their identity into a job that may not be there."
And yet we have a POTUS who is eager to buy pickaxes and shovels and send men down the mine shaft in search of coal. What is even more shocking is that there are men - and women - who buy into this notion of "bringing back jobs" in their quest to "Make America Great again."
Maybe POTUS will next invest in a horse buggy and whip factory. Welcome to "Send America back into the Dark Ages again."

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Donald Trump’s Firing of James Comey (10wed1)
asset.assetTitle: Donald Trump’s Firing of James Comey (10wed1)

taxonomies.name: Donald Trump’s Firing of James Comey (10wed1)

comments.commentBody:
This is a perilous moment indeed. Already comparisons to Watergate have been made. And with good reason.
Trump lied his way to the highest office, continues to lie, and on top of all that he and his family and in-laws are making money hand over fist.
Harry Truman made the phrase "The buck stops here" famous. Trump can make the phrase "The rot starts here" famous.

comments.commentBody:
"The fallout was contained, partly because of a news blackout and partly because France lacks an equivalent to Fox News."
Of course it helps that there was a news blackout and no Faux news. But do not underestimate the possibility that the French take their voting more seriously than Americans.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/What’s the Matter With Europe? (05krugman)
asset.assetTitle: What’s the Matter With Europe? (05krugman)

comments.commentBody:
Many problems are real, but politicians have a tendency to heighten their importance in order to incite common folk and win elections. That, by definition, is the nature of democracy. But of late, as seen in the U.K. and then here in the U.S.A., politicians whip up nonexistent issues or exaggerate their role to limits we've never seen before.
In the U.K. they advertised a shifting of sizable funds into their healthcare system. It turned out to be not true. Here in the U.S.A. they started to issue a barrage of anti-immigrant orders based on nonexistent threats such as the massacre in Bowling Green. It never happened.
The only defense against these excesses is for citizens to be well informed, engage in fact checking, and be attentive to facts. Otherwise we are not any different from the lemmings that follow a leader down the precipice.

Nothing matters other than Trump winning. Th rest might as well nor exist.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Climate of Unintended Consequences (04stephens)
asset.assetTitle: Climate of Unintended Consequences (04stephens)

comments.commentBody:
A pedestrian is calmly walking on the sidewalk when s/he sees at a distance a car that careens and seems to be out of control and coming in his/her direction.
1. S/he can do nothing and stand still and hope that the car's path veers around (after all it is out of control) leaving the pedestrian essentially unharmed.
2. S/he can jump in some direction and hope that the car's path veers differently from the direction s/he chose leaving the pedestrian essentially unharmed.
Doing nothing can be good, depending on what happens. And doing something may also be good, depending on what happens. The outcome of inaction or taking action depend on what happens in the future; this can only be estimated probabilistically prior to the decision to act or not to act. And depending on subsequent empirical analyses, further corrective action needs to be taken.
But to merely point to past mistakes an hence claim that doing nothing is the only option because doing something may be bad is incorrect. What is more important to realize is that we need to be vigilant and undertake corrective actions at frequent intervals. And that is a very different lesson from the one being advocated in this column.

all-properties.name: no-group
all-properties.description: Not in a group

asset.taxonomy: opinion/President Trump Is the Enemy of Their Enemies (04edsall)
asset.assetTitle: President Trump Is the Enemy of Their Enemies (04edsall)

taxonomies.name: President Trump Is the Enemy of Their Enemies (04edsall)

comments.commentBody:
This is a static picture of who those Americans are that are socially conservative and find their voice in Trump and hence lend their support to him. But the immigrants who have come in and become US citizens and the youth who will turn of voting age in the next four years are likely to be more liberal in their social values. And this may not bode well for Trump or candidates like him.
In other words I do expect the demographic shift to be substantial enough to make Trump and his ilk obsolete. What happened in 2016 is a combination of many forces that are unlikely to come together again in 2020.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Trump’s Degradation of the Language (01blow)
asset.assetTitle: Trump’s Degradation of the Language (01blow)

comments.commentBody:
This column reminds me of one of the best words crafted by the inimitable and irreplaceable Colbert - truthiness. It has a feeling of being truthful, it is perceived as truthful, and so it is believed to be true.

Trumpsters are like Dorothy in that they believe if they tap their feet three times, things will be better.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/On the Power of Being Awful (01krugman)
asset.assetTitle: On the Power of Being Awful (01krugman)

taxonomies.name: On the Power of Being Awful (01krugman)

comments.commentBody:
It is often said that perception is reality. I have interpreted that to mean that I'll feel good if I think I'm feeling good. And Trump, to his credit, has been feeding a lot of "feel good" experiences to his voters.
For one, about 700 jobs were saved in Indiana after a huge tax subsidy was underwritten by Indian tax payers. But to Trump supporters it felt like he accosted Carrier and negotiated successfully. From this they extrapolate and believe that he is the one to save jobs across the country.
When Assad used chemical weapons on his own people, what did Trump do? He ordered a raining of missiles. While most analysts noted that the missile attack had very limited value in damaging Assad's assets or capabilities, Trump voters saw a strong man who made America look powerful. They felt like they were on top of the world, once again.
And most recently he skipped the WHCD choosing instead to attend yet another rally. What did his supporters see? They saw a strong man snub the media and instead spent time among them, even though the reason was more likely that he needed adulation rather than ribbing.
Trump supporters see a man in shining armor riding a white horse who they expect will save America. From what is unclear. Or how is also unclear. But they feel it in their bones. And that makes it real.
Until it isn't!

asset.taxonomy: opinion/100 Days of Noise From Donald Trump (29sat1)
asset.assetTitle: 100 Days of Noise From Donald Trump (29sat1)

taxonomies.name: 100 Days of Noise From Donald Trump (29sat1)

comments.commentBody: It is said that there is but a thin line between tragedy and comedy. And the first 100 days of the Trump administration is a perfect example of that saying. It is indeed very comical to see them bumbling around, huffing and puffing with great bravado. But it masks the tragic situation we are in - defunding of science, climate change, banging the drums of war, and causing unease throughout the world.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/White House of Grifters (28egan)
asset.assetTitle: White House of Grifters (28egan)

comments.commentBody:
Nepotism and corruption are the two pillars of the Trump administration. Let's call it what it is - neporruption.
On a related note, I'd like to ask those of you who have asked those of us who supported Hillary to be kind to those of us who voted for Trump. My simple question: Whatever happened to one of their battle cries 'Corrupt Hillary?" Why should we feel any continued sympathy for the Trump voter who has suddenly developed an amnesia?

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Black People Are Not All ‘Living in Hell’ (27edsall)
asset.assetTitle: Black People Are Not All ‘Living in Hell’ (27edsall)

taxonomies.name: Black People Are Not All ‘Living in Hell’ (27edsall)

comments.commentBody:
Thank you for sharing a treasure trove of rich data that more clearly shows the actual economic condition of black people. But it will easily be dismissed by Trumpsters as alternate facts; after all why would they believe anybody who belongs to a fake university or fake newspaper.
And the reason for their dismissal of this analysis is simple: unless you project an 'indiscriminate portrayal of African-Americans" how can you continue to ACTUALLY DISCRIMINATE. Plain and simple once you see it through Trump's lens.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Trump’s Can’t-Do Record (27collins)
asset.assetTitle: Trump’s Can’t-Do Record (27collins)

comments.commentBody:
If the Federal government has to be shuttered tomorrow for lack of funding, Trump's supporters can say that he has run the government just like he has run his businesses - into insolvency.
And that is no mean achievement for a shade under 100 days.

asset.taxonomy: climate/Today’s Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal (todays-energy-jobs-are-in-solar-not-coal)
asset.assetTitle: Today’s Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal (todays-energy-jobs-are-in-solar-not-coal)

taxonomies.name: Today’s Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal (todays-energy-jobs-are-in-solar-not-coal)

comments.commentBody:
Focusing on bringing back jobs in the coal mining industry is like trying to get us all to travel in a horse and buggy. I think even coal miners will resist that.
But, somehow, our liar-in-chief managed to convince enough folks that reviving jobs in coal mining is both useful and important. And here is the double whammy on those folks waiting to get back into the mines. Most of their jobs have been taken over by machines and for those that did actually mine, their healthcare is under attack.
So, not only are those coal mining jobs not coming back, but for those whose health was adversely afflicted in the coal mines, good luck getting proper healthcare.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/All I Know Is What I Read in the Fake News (25conversation)
asset.assetTitle: All I Know Is What I Read in the Fake News (25conversation)

taxonomies.name: All I Know Is What I Read in the Fake News (25conversation)

comments.commentBody:
Matt Labash is a lot more interesting than Arthur Brooks, although that was a low threshold to cross. As seems to be the case with many things including the POTUS these days. He does have a better sense of humor than his immediate predecessor although Gail Collins wins the gold!
Nonetheless I have a few points of disagreement with him. He accuses Team Blue (a nice term, thank you for introducing it to me) "of squirting down the working class’s leg while telling them that it’s raining" while conveniently forgetting it is technology that is killing more jobs than immigrants, legal or illegal.
He notes that he "distrust “my side” nearly as much as I distrust yours" meaning that he has no faith in Team Blue or Team Red. That is no argument because we need some form of governance structure. I suppose we could have more political parties with more color codes, but merely noting that neither side is "trustworthy" makes no sense. Part of the reason is the entrenched Congressmen/women who through legislative processes carve out districts that help them get reelected. Is Matt ready to call for an amendment that shifts redistricting to nonpartisan panels?

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Resilience of the Resistance (24blow)
asset.assetTitle: Resilience of the Resistance (24blow)

comments.commentBody:
Trump definitely has helped mobilize people "who previously didn’t pay very much attention to what happens in Washington." He has also successfully "politicized many formerly apolitical people."
But the true test will be in the 2018 mid-term elections. How many of these energized and politicized folks will come out and vote to throw out their ineffective representatives? That and that alone will be the true test of the strength and ultimate success of the resilience of this resistance.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Zombies of Voodoo Economics (24krugman)
asset.assetTitle: Zombies of Voodoo Economics (24krugman)

comments.commentBody:
"For Mr. Trump sold himself to voters as unorthodox as well as effective."
Most of the country, actually a majority, knew that he was maybe unorthodox, actually crazy is more like it, but definitely ineffective. However, many others fell for his smoke and mirrors.
This emperor has no clothes and by now even his supporters should be able to see that.
